segment.source: Create an Authentication Exemption List Rule (Windows 10)
segment.target: Create an Authentication Exemption List Rule (Windows 10)

segment.source: Create an Authentication Exemption List Rule
segment.target: Create an Authentication Exemption List Rule

segment.source: Create an Authentication Exemption List Rule
segment.target: Create an Authentication Exemption List Rule

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: In almost any isolated server or isolated domain scenario, there are some devices or devices that cannot communicate by using IPsec.
segment.target: In almost any isolated server or isolated domain scenario, there are some devices or devices that cannot communicate by using IPsec.

segment.source: This procedure shows you how to create rules that exempt those devices from the authentication requirements of your isolation policies.
segment.target: This procedure shows you how to create rules that exempt those devices from the authentication requirements of your isolation policies.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Adding devices to the exemption list for a zone reduces security because it permits devices in the zone to send network traffic that is unprotected by IPsec to the devices on the list.
segment.target: Adding devices to the exemption list for a zone reduces security because it permits devices in the zone to send network traffic that is unprotected by IPsec to the devices on the list.

segment.source: As discussed in the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design Guide, you must add only managed and trusted devices to the exemption list.
segment.target: As discussed in the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security Design Guide, you must add only managed and trusted devices to the exemption list.

segment.source: Administrative credentials
segment.target: Administrative credentials

segment.source: To complete these procedures, you must be a member of the Domain Administrators group, or otherwise be delegated permissions to modify the GPOs.
segment.target: To complete these procedures, you must be a member of the Domain Administrators group, or otherwise be delegated permissions to modify the GPOs.

segment.source: To create a rule that exempts specified hosts from authentication
segment.target: To create a rule that exempts specified hosts from authentication

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Management Console to Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Management Console to Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.

segment.source: In the navigation pane, click Connection Security Rules.
segment.target: In the navigation pane, click Connection Security Rules.

segment.source: Click Action, and then click New Rule.
segment.target: Click Action, and then click New Rule.

segment.source: On the Rule Type page of the New Connection Security Rule Wizard, click Authentication exemption, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Rule Type page of the New Connection Security Rule Wizard, click Authentication exemption, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Exempt Computers page, to create a new exemption, click Add.
segment.target: On the Exempt Computers page, to create a new exemption, click Add.

segment.source: To modify an existing exemption, click it, and then click Edit.
segment.target: To modify an existing exemption, click it, and then click Edit.

segment.source: In the IP Address dialog box, do one of the following:
segment.target: In the IP Address dialog box, do one of the following:

segment.source: To add a single IP address, click This IP address or subnet, type the IP address of the host in the text box, and then click OK.
segment.target: To add a single IP address, click This IP address or subnet, type the IP address of the host in the text box, and then click OK.

segment.source: To add an entire subnet by address, click This IP address or subnet, and then type the IP address of the subnet, followed by a forward slash (/) and the number of bits in the corresponding subnet mask.
segment.target: To add an entire subnet by address, click This IP address or subnet, and then type the IP address of the subnet, followed by a forward slash (/) and the number of bits in the corresponding subnet mask.

segment.source: For example, 10.50.0.0/16 represents the class B subnet that begins with address 10.50.0.1, and ends with address 10.50.255.254.
segment.target: For example, 10.50.0.0/16 represents the class B subnet that begins with address 10.50.0.1, and ends with address 10.50.255.254.

segment.source: Click OK when you are finished.
segment.target: Click OK when you are finished.

segment.source: To add the local device’s subnet, click Predefined set of computers, select Local subnet from the list, and then click OK.
segment.target: To add the local device’s subnet, click Predefined set of computers, select Local subnet from the list, and then click OK.

segment.source: Note: If you select the local subnet from the list rather than typing the subnet address in manually, the device automatically adjusts the active local subnet to match the device’s current IP address.
segment.target: Note: If you select the local subnet from the list rather than typing the subnet address in manually, the device automatically adjusts the active local subnet to match the device’s current IP address.

segment.source: To add a discrete range of addresses that do not correspond to a subnet, click This IP address range, type the beginning and ending IP addresses in the From and To text boxes, and then click OK.
segment.target: To add a discrete range of addresses that do not correspond to a subnet, click This IP address range, type the beginning and ending IP addresses in the From and To text boxes, and then click OK.

segment.source: To exempt all of the remote hosts that the local device uses for a specified network service, click Predefined set of computers, select the network service from the list, and then click OK.
segment.target: To exempt all of the remote hosts that the local device uses for a specified network service, click Predefined set of computers, select the network service from the list, and then click OK.

segment.source: Repeat steps 5 and 6 for each exemption that you need to create.
segment.target: Repeat steps 5 and 6 for each exemption that you need to create.

segment.source: Click Next when you have created all of the exemptions.
segment.target: Click Next when you have created all of the exemptions.

segment.source: On the Profile page, check the profile for each network location type to which this set of exemptions applies, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Profile page, check the profile for each network location type to which this set of exemptions applies, and then click Next.

segment.source: Caution: If all of the exemptions are on the organization’s network and that network is managed by an Active Directory domain, then consider restricting the rule to the Domain profile only.
segment.target: Caution: If all of the exemptions are on the organization’s network and that network is managed by an Active Directory domain, then consider restricting the rule to the Domain profile only.

segment.source: Selecting the wrong profile can reduce the protection for your computer because any computer with an IP address that matches an exemption rule will not be required to authenticate.
segment.target: Selecting the wrong profile can reduce the protection for your computer because any computer with an IP address that matches an exemption rule will not be required to authenticate.

segment.source: On the Name page, type the name of the exemption rule, type a description, and then click Finish.
segment.target: On the Name page, type the name of the exemption rule, type a description, and then click Finish.
